javaslang.collection

Interface BinaryTree<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of a tree node's value.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<T>, Tree<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BinaryTree.AbstractBinaryTree, BinaryTree.Branch, BinaryTree.Leaf, BinaryTree.Nil

    public interface BinaryTree<T>
extends Tree<T>
    A binary tree implementation where each node keeps a value.

    A binary tree consists of branches (nodes with children) and leaves (nodes without children). A branch has a left and a right child, at least one child is not Nil. The empty tree is represented by Nil. 

         BinaryTree = Nil | Leaf(value) | Branch(BinaryTree left, value, BinaryTree right)
    See also Binary tree (wikipedia).
    Since:
    1.1.0

    • Nested Class Summary

      static class  BinaryTree.AbstractBinaryTree<T>
      An abstract binary tree implementation which just overrides equals, hashCode and toString.
      static class  BinaryTree.Branch<T>
      Representation of a binary tree branch.
      static class  BinaryTree.Leaf<T>
      Representation of a binary tree leaf.
      static class  BinaryTree.Nil<T>
      The singleton instance of the empty binary tree.

    • Method Detail

      • of

        static <T> BinaryTree<T> of(BinaryTree<T> left,
                            T value,
                            BinaryTree<T> right)
        Creates a either a binary tree branch or a leaf, depending on the children left and right. By definition, a binary tree node with two Nil children is a leaf.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The value type
        Parameters:
        left - Left subtree
        value - A value
        right - Right subtree
        Returns:
        A new, non-empty binary tree

      • branch

        static <T> BinaryTree.Branch<T> branch(BinaryTree<T> left,
                                       T value,
                                       BinaryTree<T> right)
        Throws if left and right are Nil - if in doubt, use BinaryTree.of(left, value, right) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        T - Component type
        Parameters:
        left - Left subtree
        value - A value
        right - Right subtree
        Returns:
        A new binary tree branch
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if left or right is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if left and right are empty (Nil)

      • balance

        static <T> BinaryTree<T> balance(Iterable<T> iterable)

        Converts an Iterable to a balanced binary tree.

        Example: BinaryTree.balance(List.of(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)) = (1 (2 3 4) (5 6))

        Type Parameters:
        T - Element type
        Parameters:
        iterable - An Iterable
        Returns:
        A balanced tree containing all elements of the given iterable.

      • balance

        @SafeVarargs
static <T> BinaryTree<T> balance(T... elements)

        Converts the given elements to a balanced binary tree.

        Example: BinaryTree.balance(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) = (1 (2 3 4) (5 6))

        Type Parameters:
        T - Element type
        Parameters:
        elements - Elements
        Returns:
        A balanced tree containing all given elements.

      • balance

        default BinaryTree<T> balance()
        Returns the balanced version of this tree, i.e. the tree where all subtrees have minimal depth.
        Returns:
        The balanced version of this binary tree.

      • getChildren

        List<BinaryTree<T>> getChildren()
        Description copied from interface: Tree
        Returns the List of children of this tree.
        Specified by:
        getChildren in interface Tree<T>
        Returns:
        The empty list, if this is the empty tree or a leaf, otherwise the non-empty list of children.

        The left branch if this BinaryTree is a Node.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this BinaryTree is Nil
